metadata.title: Biotechnological applications of nanomaterials for air pollution and water/wastewater treatment

sections.text:
2214-7853© 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of INN International Conference/Workshop on “Nanotechnology and Nanomedicine’’ NTNM2017.
Environmental contamination, principally caused by the toxic chemicals from human activities or industrial processes, includes air, water, and soil contamination. Therefore, the development of highly efficient methods for providing an appropriate environment is needed for the industrialized countries. Nanotechnology provides novel treatment approaches and creates new technologies with superior advantages compare to the conventional techniques. Through the present research, the recent developments in nanotechnology have been reviewed, and potential applications of nanomaterials for the removal of pollutants from air, water and wastewater have been discussed.
© 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Selection and/or Peer-review under responsibility of INN International Conference/Workshop on “Nanotechnology and Nanomedicine’’ NTNM2017.
Keywords: Nanotechnology, Water treatment, Air pollution, Nanomaterials
* Correspondence: Abolfazl Akbarzadeh and Ziba Sabet. Tel/Fax: 984133341933. E-mail: akbarzadehab@tbzmed.ac.ir
Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558 15551

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The environment of the industrialized countries is filled with several types of pollutants discharged from human activities or industrial processes, such as carbon monoxide (CO), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), heavy metals (arsenic, chromium, lead, cadmium, mercury and zinc), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, organic compounds (volatile organic compounds and dioxins), sulfur dioxide and particulates [1, 2]. Acid rain is caused by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide existing in the air which permeates and pollutes the soil [2]. Human activities, such as oil, coal and gas burning are the main reasons exalted the levels of nitrogen and sulfur dioxide in the air [2, 3, 4]. In addition to the air pollution and soil, there is also water pollution caused by several factors, including waste disposal, leak of fertilizers, oil spills, herbicides and pesticides, by-products of the industrial processes, burning and extraction of fossil fuels [5]. Contaminants are usually found mixed in the air, water and soil. Thus, the used technology (nanotechnology) is able to monitor, detect and, clean the contaminants from the air, water and soil is need.
Nanotechnology deals with materials on the Nano scale that often possesses the novel size-dependent properties different from their large counterparts. Alternatively, nanotechnology presents the ability to control the matter at the nanoscale and produces materials with the specific properties and functions [6]. The small size and high surface area to volume ratio of the nanomaterial can be used to detect the high-sensitive contaminants [7]. Applications of the nanotechnology such as decreasing use of raw and invented materials, reducing or removing the production of wastes and effluents, and decreasing toxics, also applications that more efficiently clean the waste streams and remediate existing contaminated sites can be useful to the environmental protection [8, 9].
So, three major applications of the nanotechnology in the fields of environment can be classified, namely (1) treatment and remediation, (2) pollution sensing and detection and (3) pollution prevention. There is great hope that nanotechnology will lead to a cleaner and healthier environment [10]. The present study focuses on the applications of the nanotechnology in water, wastewater and air treatment.

sections.heading: 2. Potential applications of nanotechnology for water, wastewater and air treatment adsorption
sections.text:
Adsorption is the adhesion of atoms, ions, or molecules of gases or solutions to a surface [11-13]. Adsorbents are solids which are utilized to adsorb the gases or dissolved substances, and the adsorbed molecules are commonly mentioned as the adsorbate [14]. Adsorption is the favorable technique used for the purification of the wastewaters from dyes and heavy metals.
Nano-adsorbents, due to their high specific surface area and connected sorption sites, short intraparticle dispersion distance, and tunable pore size and surface chemistry, show a significantly higher rate of adsorption for the organic compounds compared with the granular and powder activated carbon which has the intrinsic limitations such as surface-active sites and the activation energy of sorption [12, 15].

sections.heading: 2.1. Carbon based nano-adsorbents (Carbon nanotubes)
sections.text:
Because Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs) have unique physical and chemical properties such as high specific surface area, highly assessable adsorption sites and an adjustable surface chemistry, they are the favorite adsorbent among the carbon-based Nano-adsorbents [16-21]. There are two main types of CNTs: single-walled (SWCNTs) and multiwalled (MWCNTs).
CNTs, because of the hydrophobicity of their graphitic surface form loose aggregates in the aqueous phase, decrease the efficient surface area [22]. Also, the interstitial spaces and grooves existing in CNT aggregates are high adsorption energy sites for the organic molecules [23].
Four possible sites in CNT aggregate for the adsorption of the different pollutants [24-26] including: 1. Internal sites which are hollow inner of the distinct nanotubes 2. Interstitial channels (ICs) which are the interstitial channels between the distinct nanotubes in the aggregates 3. Grooves existent on the periphery of a nanotube aggregate and the outer surface of the outermost nanotubes 4. Outside surface which is turned surface of the distinct nanotubes on the outside of the nanotube aggregates
15552 Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558
On account of the production of oxidative stress in bacteria and destroying the cell membranes, CNTs illustrate the antimicrobial properties against a wide range of microorganisms containing bacteria such as E. coli and Salmonella [27-29] and viruses [30, 31].
A significant advantage use of CNTs over the conventional disinfection processes such as chlorination and ozonation is the production of no toxic byproducts, while the chemical oxidation occurs [13, 32].
The adsorption of the cyanobacterial toxins on CNTs, due to the wide specific surface area, exterior diameter of CNTs, and large constitution of mesoporous volume, is also higher in comparison with the carbon-based adsorbents principally [33, 34]. Many of the polar organic compounds adsorb-mechanism by the CNTs is due to the different contaminated-CNT interactions including the hydrophobic effect, π-π interactions, hydrogen bonding, covalent bonding, and the electrostatic interactions [35]. CNTs provide chemically the inert surfaces for the physical adsorption, and their high specific surface areas stand similarity with those of the activated carbons (ACs). Also, CNTs structure at the atomic scale is far more known and uniform in comparison with ACs [24]. Applications of CNTs for eliminating the dangerous contaminants from air [36], water and wastewater [37], due to their wide specific surface area, highly porous and hollow structure, light mass density and firm interaction between CNTs and contaminant molecules [38] were studied via the theoretical estimations, experimental measurements, and molecular simulations.
Oxidized and hydroxylated CNTs were excellent adsorbents for metals and had the strong adsorption capacity for the metal ions. The surface functional groups of CNTs such as carboxyl, hydroxyl, and phenol were the main adsorption sites for the metal ions which adsorb mainly through the electrostatic attraction and chemical bonding [39]. Also, the unfunctionalized CNTs surface was demonstrated to have the higher adsorption capacity for the nonpolar compounds [40]. The adsorption capacity of the CNTs could significantly increase by the surface oxidation. In several studies, CNTs have been reported as the better adsorbents than ACs for heavy metals such as Cu2+, Pb2+, Cd2+, and Zn2+ [41, 42], and the adsorption kinetics on CNTs has been fast because of the highly accessible adsorption sites and the short intraparticle diffusion distance.
Wastewater resulted from the industrial, domestic or agricultural sources includes a broad range of contaminants which unfavorably affect the quality of water. CNTs are considered as the strong adsorbents for contaminants found in the wastewater such as dioxin [43], polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [44], DDT and its metabolites [45], PBDEs [46], chlorobenzenes and chlorophenols [7], trihalomethanes [48], bisphenol A and nonylphenol [49], phthalate esters [50], dyes [1], pesticides (thiamethoxam, imidacloprid and acetamiprid) [2] and herbicides such as sulfur on derivatives [5], atrazine [4] and dicamba [5] which are non-degradable, highly toxic and carcinogenic. CNTs, with high specific surface area and controlled pore size distribution, include the excellent sorption capability and efficiency compared to the conventional granular and powder ACs. In addition, CNTs have used as the Nanofilters to decrease the particle concentrations in wastewater [6-5].
Due to the electrical, electrochemical and optical properties of CNTs, they were used for trapping the greenhouse gas emissions, sensing elements to detect and monitor the concentration of the toxic gases released in the environment and cleaning these gases [5, 6]. CNTs include the trapping capacity gases up to a hundred times faster than other methods. CNT-based gas sensors have several advantages over the conventional metal oxide semiconductor gas sensors such as low power consumption, low operating temperature, and high sensitivity [6]. The mentioned sensors have been used in several investigations for detecting the nitrogen oxides (NOx) [6], nitrogen dioxide (NO2) [3], ammonia (NH3) [6], and sulfur dioxide (SO2) [5] at room temperature.
Trap mechanism of the dioxin is a strong interaction between the two benzene rings of dioxin and the surface of CNTs. Dioxin molecules interact with the whole surface of CNT with a porous wall and the probability of overlapping events which raise the adsorption potential inside the pores, too [6].

sections.heading: 2.2. Metal-based nano-adsorbents (Metal oxides)
sections.text:
Metal oxides as iron oxide and titanium dioxide are effective, low cost adsorbents for types of heavy metals like arsenic, lead, mercury, copper, cadmium, chromium, nickel, and radionuclides. The stated Nano-absorbents showed the great potential to compete ACs [7]. The advantages technologically and economically of the metal oxides absorbents include the high adsorption capacity, easy separation and regeneration.
There is a two-step process for sorption of heavy metal by the metal oxidase Nano-absorbents:
Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558 15553
1. Fast adsorption of the metal ions on the outside surface, 2. Rate-limiting intraparticle diffusion along with the micropore walls [8]. Usually, the metal-based Nano-absorbents such as nanometals and nanometal oxides are compacted into the porous pellets or used in powders for the industrial use. Nanometal oxides such as TiO2, iron oxide and Nanomagnetite have capability superior than the AC for the arsenic adsorption [9]. Iron oxides are nanomaterials which can powerfully adsorb the metals in soils as well as arsenic. In general, adding Nano size metal oxides to the soils will fix the soil metals [70]. Some iron oxide nanoparticles such as Nano-maghemite and Nano-magnetite are superparamagnetic which can promote the separation and recovery by a low-gradient magnetic field [12]. Pan et al. in a study reported that Nano size magnetite particles can be used to fix the phosphate in soil by adsorption [7].
Nano iron hydroxide [α-FeO(OH)] were used for absorbing the arsenic from waste and drinking water [2]. The gas sensors which were used for finding air pollutants were manufactured by coating a metal oxide (such as tin oxide (SnO2), zinc oxide (ZnO), titanium oxide (TiO2) and tungsten oxide (WO3)) layer on a substrate with two electrodes. When the metal oxide sensor exposed to the pollutant gas, a change occurred in the resistance of the sensor-related to the sensor resistance in background air [3, 4].

sections.heading: 2.3. Polymeric nano-adsorbents
sections.text:
Dendrimers are the polymeric Nano-adsorbents which were used for removing the organics and heavy metals by sorption based on the complexation, electrostatic interactions, hydrophobic effect, and hydrogen bonding [5]. Dendrimers are relatively monodispersed and repeatedly branched molecules and consisting of three components: a core, hydrophobic interior shells for sorption of the organic compounds and tailored exterior branches for absorbing the heavy metals [12, 6-8]. Diallo et al., mixed the dendrimers in order to remove copper from water in an ultrafiltration device [9].
Zeolite with extremely porous structure is a suitable case for embedding the silver ions. Silver ions are released from the zeolite matrix by replacing with other cations in solution [13, 8]. When zeolite is used for the sanitary objectives, the silver inhibits the growth of microbes [1]. Zeolites have the high efficiency and suitability with existing the water treatment systems since they can be implemented in beads and pellets for the steady absorbers [13]. Ion-exchange zeolites are one of technologies to remove the emissions of NOx (mixture of NO and NO2) from fossil fuel combustion at low temperatures [3].
Membrane processes and membranes are cost-effective and feasible for water and wastewater treatment that enabling water reuse and can be better choice in comparison with the traditional treatment systems due to their high efficiency in eliminating the pollutants [2]. Membranes provide a physical barrier for substances based on the pore size and molecule size which enables the use of the unconventional water sources [12]. The high energy consumption, membrane fouling and the complexity of the process design and operation are the main limitations to the broad application of the pressure driven membrane processes. Furthermore, these limitations decrease the life time of membranes and membrane components [12]. Functional nanoparticles have been frequently used in manufacturing the membranes to enhance the membrane permeability, fouling resistance, thermal and mechanical stability, and represent the new functions for contaminating the degradation and self-cleaning [3, 8]. On account of the size prevention and deepness filtration, filtration membranes along with the radially aligned CNTs have high efficacy in removal bacteria and viruses; therefore, they can be used as the effective water disinfection devices [5-7]. The corporation of the metal nanoparticles in membrane provides the effective degradation and dichlorination of the toxic contaminants [8].
Nanocomposite membranes are a group of membranes which include the mixed matrix membranes and surfacefunctionalized membranes and utilized for desalination. Nanofillers, which are inorganic and inserted in a polymeric or inorganic oxide matrix, are added in a matrix material of mixed matrix membranes and lead to a higher surfaceto-mass ratio in these membranes [89, 90]. The use of nanocomposite membranes can degrade a broad range of the organic and inorganic contaminants. Antimicrobial nanomaterials such as Nano-Ag, Nano-TiO2 and CNTs can enhance the antifouling properties of the nanocomposite membranes [1]. CNTs have inactivation capacity of bacteria upon the direct contact [2]. Therefore, resulting the nanocomposite membrane from the single-walled CNTs and polyvinyl-N-carbazole exhibited the high inactivation of bacteria upon the direct contact in an investigation [3].
15554 Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558

sections.heading: 2.4. Nanofiber membranes
sections.text: Electrospinning produces the nanofibers with high specific surface area and porosity whose features such as, diameter, composition, morphology, secondary structure, and spatial alignment can be controlled for the special applications [4]. Nanofiber membranes were used in separation and filtration processes of the particles from water by a high refusal rate without the important fouling and air [5]. Therefore, they were employed as the pretreatment prior to ultrafiltration or reverse osmosis (RO). Due to the tunable properties of resulting nanofibers from electro spun, multifunctional materials such as TiO2 could be simply doped into the spinning solutions for constructing the multifunctional media/membrane filters [4]. The comparability of the nanofiber materials with the sizes of microorganisms, the surface morphology, and biocompatibility and also capacity of nanofibers to be tailored to particulars such as the membrane thickness and a linked together open pore structure were their major advantages [13].

sections.heading: 2.5. Nanofiltration Membrane
sections.text:
Nanofiltration membranes are used in water and wastewater treatment because of their capacity for cleaning muddiness, microorganisms and inorganic ions from water and eliminating the organic and inorganic pollutants and organic carbon from wastewater [11, 6]. Also, they can be used for softening the groundwater by the reduction of hardness, odor, color, and heavy metal ions from groundwater and removal of the dissolved organic material and for pretreating in the seawater desalination [11]. Nanofiltration membranes have a unique charge-based repulsion mechanism that provide the separation of the various ions such as Ca and Na [7-9].
Thin Film Nanocomposite (TFN) Membrane Generally, by incorporating nanomaterials into the active layer of thin film composite (TFC) membranes could produce the thin film nanocomposite membranes with improved separation properties. Nanomaterials which included the suitable features for such applications included the Nano-zeolites, Nano- Ag, Nano-TiO2, and CNTs [12]. Nano-zeolites were the most frequently used nanomaterials in TFN which lead to enhance the membrane permeability; salt rejection, negatively charged and thicker polyamide active layer [10]. Also, Nano-zeolites could be employed as the carriers for Ag that had the antimicrobial property and revealed the anti-fouling property to the membrane [11]. TFN membranes containing Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles illustrated the slightly raised membrane rejection [12, 13]. The single-walled CNTs covalently bonded to TFN were the way for controlling the biofouling in TFN membranes [14]

sections.heading: 2.6. Nanocatalysts
sections.text:
Photocatalysis was a progressive oxidation process that had the huge potential as a low-cost, high efficiency, low energy consumption, environmental friendly and maintainable water and wastewater treatment technology and was used to oxidative elimination of the trace contaminants and microbial pathogens; especially, non-biodegradable organic contaminants, by mineralizing them to the small inorganic molecules. Therefore, more than 3000 organic contaminants whose degradation was difficult by the traditional methods could be broken down by the heterogeneous photocatalysis [1, 12]. Since there was the limited light fluence and photo catalytic activity, the slow kinetics was the main border for the broad application of photocatalysis; therefore, expanding the photo catalytic reaction kinetics and photo activity range were the main goals of common research. Photocatalysis had the applications like anti-fogging, anti-microbe, and self-cleaning surfaces, to water and air purification and solarinduced hydrogen production that many of these were used in the commercial products [1]. Among the several semiconductor photo catalysts, TiO2 was the most used one because it had the high activity, low toxicity, wide chemical stability to light illumination, and low-cost.
TiO2 photocatalyst upon absorbing a UV photon produces an electron/hole (e-/h+) pair which later either to form reactive oxygen species (ROS) migrated to the surface or undergo unwanted recombination (Fig. 1) [1]. By optimizing the particle shape and size, decreasing recombination by the noble metal doping, maximizing reactive facets and surface treatment to improve pollutant adsorption could enhance the photo activity of nano-TiO2 [19, 10]. Semiconductor-based photocatalyst like TiO2 produced very reactive oxidants, same as OH radicals, for disinfection of microorganisms, bacteria, fungi, algae, viruses.
Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558 15555
The limited photocatalytic ability of TiO2 could be enhanced with extending its optical absorbance to the visiblelight region by doping the transition metals and anionic nonmetals like nitrogen, carbon, sulfur, or fluorine intoTiO2.

sections.heading: 2.7. Fullerene
sections.text: In addition to TiO2, some fullerene derivatives like Fullerol and C60 encapsulated with poly(N-vinylpyrrolidone) also had a photocatalytic effect under the visible light radiation which produced 1O2 with lower oxidation potential and the more expensive than TiO2 [17, 18]. Fullerene nanoparticles were connected with oxidative stress responses in daphnia [19]. Fullerenes have been used for adsorption of the organic compounds which showed the weak adsorption for a broad variety of organic compounds such as phenols, PAHs, amines, whereas they have high efficiency for the removal of organometallic compounds as organ lead [10]. C60 fullerenes instinctively form the clusters in water containing nanocrystalline aggregates with toxic effect to bacteria [11]. Amino fullerenes were used to degrade the pharmaceutical compounds and inactivate viruses. On account of the amino fullerenes, positive charge are more responsive to immobilization than the fullerol and also more efficient for the disinfection process [12].

sections.heading: 2.8. ZnO
sections.text: Nitrogen-doped ZnO and palladium-incorporated ZnO nanoparticles have displayed the excellent antibacterial properties at the removal of bacteria from water (bacteria have capacity internalize of Nano sized ZnO) [13, 14]. Also, Nano sized ZnO semiconductor films were used to degradation of the organic contaminants (4-chlorocatechol) in a study [15]. As UV radiated to ZnO nanoparticles, they fluoresced. ZnO oxidizes the existing chlorinated organic pollutants in water and fluorescent signal of ZnO was decreased [9].

sections.heading: 2.9. Nano Zero-Valent Iron (nZVI)
sections.text:
Zero-valence metals as nano zero-valent iron (nZVI) were used for eliminating the environmental contaminants like PCBs, pesticides, and organic dyes because of their higher surface area, reactivity and shape associated
15556 Panahi et al. / Materials Today: Proceedings 5 (2018) 15550–15558
properties from water and wastewater [16, 27]. Since the specific surface of nZVI was high in comparison with the conventional granular iron, it was much more reactive. The life time of nZVI was very low because its reactivity was high; therefore, surface modifications were essential for stabilizing the nanoparticles .Studies have exhibited that nZVI could transform the heavy metal ions like As(III), As(V), Pb(II), Cu(II), Ni(II), and Cr(VI). Also, reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) was done by using nZVI in a study [11, 12]. In addition to the transformation of the heavy metal and inorganic ions such as nitrate and perchlorate, chlorinated organic compounds like 2,2´-dichlorobiphenyl and organic pollutants like PCBs were transformed successfully by using nZVI. Several studies investigated the use of nZVI for groundwater remediation contaminated with the chlorinated hydrocarbon fluids and perchlorates [11].
There are two techniques for using the nZVI in groundwater remediation: stabilized nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a zone of iron particles which were adsorbed on the aquifer solids or mobile nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a plume of reactive Fe particles which destroy any organic contaminants which are dissolved from a dense non-aqueous phase liquid source in the aquifer [3, 11].

sections.heading: 3. Disinfection and microbial control
sections.text:
Contamination from microorganisms, natural organic compounds, biological toxins, human pathogens and freeliving microbes may exist in ground and surface water.
Chlorine dioxide is a high-cost standard chlorine chemical disinfection and dangerous substances like chlorite and chlorate used in the manufacturing process [34]. Although, ozone disinfection has no remaining effects, it produces the unknown organic reaction products. In general, the conventional disinfectants, as the chlorine disinfectants and ozone can create the toxic disinfection by-products (DBPs) including halogenated disinfection byproducts, carcinogenic nitrosamines, bromate, etc. UV disinfection was an oxidative disinfection which produces very small DBPs, while longer exposure time and higher dosage for certain viruses is required for efficiency [12, 15].
Due to these limitations, alternative methods were developed that could improve the power of disinfection while preventing DBP formation. Several nanomaterials, including nano-TiO2, nano-Ag, nano-ZnO, CNTs and fullerenes showed the antimicrobial properties with lower tendency to form DBPs and without strong oxidation. The antimicrobial mechanisms of Nano-TiO2, Nano-ZnO, fullerenes and CNTs were discussed in previous sections. Thus, only a brief update mainly regarding Nano-Ag nanomaterials may be provided here.

sections.heading: 4. Nano silver
sections.text: Due to the low toxicity and a strong and broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity of silver in water, silver nanoparticles most widely were used in the water treatment. The mechanism’s antimicrobial activity of Ag nanoparticles included the formation of free radicals damaging the bacterial membranes, interactions with DNA, adhesion to cell surface altering the membrane properties, and enzyme damage. Ag nanoparticles also were used in water filtration membranes; for example, in poly sulfone membranes, for biofouling reduction and had strong effect against the variety of bacteria and viruses such as antimicrobial activities against E. coli, Pseudomonas, and so forth.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: There is a significant need for safe air and water in the developed countries because of increasing population, prolonged droughts, climate change, and so forth. The unique properties of the nanomaterials like large surface areas, size, shape, and dimensions made them attractive materials for air, water and wastewater treatment applications like adsorption, disinfection, and membrane separations. The most significant advantages of the nanomaterials in comparison with the conventional treatment technologies is their capability to integrate the different properties which create the multifunctional systems as the nanocomposite membranes which have capacity for the particle retention and removal of contaminants [13]. However, there are still some disadvantages in treatment processes by nanotechnology. One of the important disadvantages is release and emit of nanoparticles to the environment; consequently, they are accumulated for the long periods of time [13].

referenceMentions.context: The environment of the industrialized countries is filled with several types of pollutants discharged from human activities or industrial processes, such as carbon monoxide (CO), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), heavy metals (arsenic, chromium, lead, cadmium, mercury and zinc), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, organic compounds (volatile organic compounds and dioxins), sulfur dioxide and particulates [1, 2].

The environment of the industrialized countries is filled with several types of pollutants discharged from human activities or industrial processes, such as carbon monoxide (CO), chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), heavy metals (arsenic, chromium, lead, cadmium, mercury and zinc), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxides, organic compounds (volatile organic compounds and dioxins), sulfur dioxide and particulates [1, 2].
Acid rain is caused by sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide existing in the air which permeates and pollutes the soil [2].
Human activities, such as oil, coal and gas burning are the main reasons exalted the levels of nitrogen and sulfur dioxide in the air [2, 3, 4].
Human activities, such as oil, coal and gas burning are the main reasons exalted the levels of nitrogen and sulfur dioxide in the air [2, 3, 4].

In addition to the air pollution and soil, there is also water pollution caused by several factors, including waste disposal, leak of fertilizers, oil spills, herbicides and pesticides, by-products of the industrial processes, burning and extraction of fossil fuels [5].
Alternatively, nanotechnology presents the ability to control the matter at the nanoscale and produces materials with the specific properties and functions [6].
The small size and high surface area to volume ratio of the nanomaterial can be used to detect the high-sensitive contaminants [7].

Applications of the nanotechnology such as decreasing use of raw and invented materials, reducing or removing the production of wastes and effluents, and decreasing toxics, also applications that more efficiently clean the waste streams and remediate existing contaminated sites can be useful to the environmental protection [8, 9].

Applications of the nanotechnology such as decreasing use of raw and invented materials, reducing or removing the production of wastes and effluents, and decreasing toxics, also applications that more efficiently clean the waste streams and remediate existing contaminated sites can be useful to the environmental protection [8, 9].
There is great hope that nanotechnology will lead to a cleaner and healthier environment [10].
Adsorption is the adhesion of atoms, ions, or molecules of gases or solutions to a surface [11-13].
Adsorption is the adhesion of atoms, ions, or molecules of gases or solutions to a surface [11-13].
Adsorption is the adhesion of atoms, ions, or molecules of gases or solutions to a surface [11-13].

Nano-adsorbents, due to their high specific surface area and connected sorption sites, short intraparticle dispersion distance, and tunable pore size and surface chemistry, show a significantly higher rate of adsorption for the organic compounds compared with the granular and powder activated carbon which has the intrinsic limitations such as surface-active sites and the activation energy of sorption [12, 15].

Nano-adsorbents, due to their high specific surface area and connected sorption sites, short intraparticle dispersion distance, and tunable pore size and surface chemistry, show a significantly higher rate of adsorption for the organic compounds compared with the granular and powder activated carbon which has the intrinsic limitations such as surface-active sites and the activation energy of sorption [12, 15].

Because Carbon Nanotubes (CNTs) have unique physical and chemical properties such as high specific surface area, highly assessable adsorption sites and an adjustable surface chemistry, they are the favorite adsorbent among the carbon-based Nano-adsorbents [16-21].

CNTs, because of the hydrophobicity of their graphitic surface form loose aggregates in the aqueous phase, decrease the efficient surface area [22].
Also, the interstitial spaces and grooves existing in CNT aggregates are high adsorption energy sites for the organic molecules [23].

A significant advantage use of CNTs over the conventional disinfection processes such as chlorination and ozonation is the production of no toxic byproducts, while the chemical oxidation occurs [13, 32].

A significant advantage use of CNTs over the conventional disinfection processes such as chlorination and ozonation is the production of no toxic byproducts, while the chemical oxidation occurs [13, 32].

The adsorption of the cyanobacterial toxins on CNTs, due to the wide specific surface area, exterior diameter of CNTs, and large constitution of mesoporous volume, is also higher in comparison with the carbon-based adsorbents principally [33, 34].

The adsorption of the cyanobacterial toxins on CNTs, due to the wide specific surface area, exterior diameter of CNTs, and large constitution of mesoporous volume, is also higher in comparison with the carbon-based adsorbents principally [33, 34].

Many of the polar organic compounds adsorb-mechanism by the CNTs is due to the different contaminated-CNT interactions including the hydrophobic effect, π-π interactions, hydrogen bonding, covalent bonding, and the electrostatic interactions [35].
Also, CNTs structure at the atomic scale is far more known and uniform in comparison with ACs [24].

Applications of CNTs for eliminating the dangerous contaminants from air [36], water and wastewater [37], due to their wide specific surface area, highly porous and hollow structure, light mass density and firm interaction between CNTs and contaminant molecules [38] were studied via the theoretical estimations, experimental measurements, and molecular simulations.

Applications of CNTs for eliminating the dangerous contaminants from air [36], water and wastewater [37], due to their wide specific surface area, highly porous and hollow structure, light mass density and firm interaction between CNTs and contaminant molecules [38] were studied via the theoretical estimations, experimental measurements, and molecular simulations.

Applications of CNTs for eliminating the dangerous contaminants from air [36], water and wastewater [37], due to their wide specific surface area, highly porous and hollow structure, light mass density and firm interaction between CNTs and contaminant molecules [38] were studied via the theoretical estimations, experimental measurements, and molecular simulations.

The surface functional groups of CNTs such as carboxyl, hydroxyl, and phenol were the main adsorption sites for the metal ions which adsorb mainly through the electrostatic attraction and chemical bonding [39].
Also, the unfunctionalized CNTs surface was demonstrated to have the higher adsorption capacity for the nonpolar compounds [40].

In several studies, CNTs have been reported as the better adsorbents than ACs for heavy metals such as Cu2+, Pb2+, Cd2+, and Zn2+ [41, 42], and the adsorption kinetics on CNTs has been fast because of the highly accessible adsorption sites and the short intraparticle diffusion distance.

In several studies, CNTs have been reported as the better adsorbents than ACs for heavy metals such as Cu2+, Pb2+, Cd2+, and Zn2+ [41, 42], and the adsorption kinetics on CNTs has been fast because of the highly accessible adsorption sites and the short intraparticle diffusion distance.

CNTs are considered as the strong adsorbents for contaminants found in the wastewater such as dioxin [43], polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [44], DDT and its metabolites [45], PBDEs [46], chlorobenzenes and chlorophenols [7], trihalomethanes [48], bisphenol A and nonylphenol [49], phthalate esters [50], dyes [1], pesticides (thiamethoxam, imidacloprid and acetamiprid) [2] and herbicides such as sulfur on derivatives [5], atrazine [4] and dicamba [5] which are non-degradable, highly toxic and carcinogenic.

TFN membranes containing Ag and TiO2 nanoparticles illustrated the slightly raised membrane rejection [12, 13].
Therefore, more than 3000 organic contaminants whose degradation was difficult by the traditional methods could be broken down by the heterogeneous photocatalysis [1, 12].
Therefore, more than 3000 organic contaminants whose degradation was difficult by the traditional methods could be broken down by the heterogeneous photocatalysis [1, 12].

Photocatalysis had the applications like anti-fogging, anti-microbe, and self-cleaning surfaces, to water and air purification and solarinduced hydrogen production that many of these were used in the commercial products [1].

By optimizing the particle shape and size, decreasing recombination by the noble metal doping, maximizing reactive facets and surface treatment to improve pollutant adsorption could enhance the photo activity of nano-TiO2 [19, 10].

By optimizing the particle shape and size, decreasing recombination by the noble metal doping, maximizing reactive facets and surface treatment to improve pollutant adsorption could enhance the photo activity of nano-TiO2 [19, 10].
Scheme depicting the pollutant removal through the formation of the photo-induced charge carriers (e/h) in TiO2 nanoparticle surfaces [50].

In addition to TiO2, some fullerene derivatives like Fullerol and C60 encapsulated with poly(N-vinylpyrrolidone) also had a photocatalytic effect under the visible light radiation which produced 1O2 with lower oxidation potential and the more expensive than TiO2 [17, 18].

In addition to TiO2, some fullerene derivatives like Fullerol and C60 encapsulated with poly(N-vinylpyrrolidone) also had a photocatalytic effect under the visible light radiation which produced 1O2 with lower oxidation potential and the more expensive than TiO2 [17, 18].
Fullerene nanoparticles were connected with oxidative stress responses in daphnia [19].

Fullerenes have been used for adsorption of the organic compounds which showed the weak adsorption for a broad variety of organic compounds such as phenols, PAHs, amines, whereas they have high efficiency for the removal of organometallic compounds as organ lead [10].
C60 fullerenes instinctively form the clusters in water containing nanocrystalline aggregates with toxic effect to bacteria [11].
On account of the amino fullerenes, positive charge are more responsive to immobilization than the fullerol and also more efficient for the disinfection process [12].

Nitrogen-doped ZnO and palladium-incorporated ZnO nanoparticles have displayed the excellent antibacterial properties at the removal of bacteria from water (bacteria have capacity internalize of Nano sized ZnO) [13, 14].
Also, Nano sized ZnO semiconductor films were used to degradation of the organic contaminants (4-chlorocatechol) in a study [15].
ZnO oxidizes the existing chlorinated organic pollutants in water and fluorescent signal of ZnO was decreased [9].
properties from water and wastewater [16, 27].
properties from water and wastewater [16, 27].
Also, reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) was done by using nZVI in a study [11, 12].
Also, reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III) was done by using nZVI in a study [11, 12].
Several studies investigated the use of nZVI for groundwater remediation contaminated with the chlorinated hydrocarbon fluids and perchlorates [11].

There are two techniques for using the nZVI in groundwater remediation: stabilized nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a zone of iron particles which were adsorbed on the aquifer solids or mobile nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a plume of reactive Fe particles which destroy any organic contaminants which are dissolved from a dense non-aqueous phase liquid source in the aquifer [3, 11].

There are two techniques for using the nZVI in groundwater remediation: stabilized nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a zone of iron particles which were adsorbed on the aquifer solids or mobile nZVI is injected into the groundwater and formed a plume of reactive Fe particles which destroy any organic contaminants which are dissolved from a dense non-aqueous phase liquid source in the aquifer [3, 11].
Chlorine dioxide is a high-cost standard chlorine chemical disinfection and dangerous substances like chlorite and chlorate used in the manufacturing process [34].
UV disinfection was an oxidative disinfection which produces very small DBPs, while longer exposure time and higher dosage for certain viruses is required for efficiency [12, 15].
UV disinfection was an oxidative disinfection which produces very small DBPs, while longer exposure time and higher dosage for certain viruses is required for efficiency [12, 15].

The most significant advantages of the nanomaterials in comparison with the conventional treatment technologies is their capability to integrate the different properties which create the multifunctional systems as the nanocomposite membranes which have capacity for the particle retention and removal of contaminants [13].
One of the important disadvantages is release and emit of nanoparticles to the environment; consequently, they are accumulated for the long periods of time [13].

metadata.abstractText: Environmental contamination, principally caused by the toxic chemicals from human activities or industrial processes, includes air, water, and soil contamination. Therefore, the development of highly efficient methods for providing an appropriate environment is needed for the industrialized countries. Nanotechnology provides novel treatment approaches and creates new technologies with superior advantages compare to the conventional techniques. Through the present research, the recent developments in nanotechnology have been reviewed, and potential applications of nanomaterials for the removal of pollutants from air, water and wastewater have been discussed. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd.
